title: Risk Appetite Statement
body_md:
Overview: {{firm.name}} risk appetite reflects its strategic focus on providing secure, compliant financial services within a well-defined operational scope. The risk appetite statement establishes the parameters for financial crime risk management and guides decision-making processes. It is reviewed quarterly to ensure alignment with evolving business needs and regulatory landscapes.

Core Principles: {{firm.name}} adopts a conservative risk appetite, particularly in areas associated with financial crime, and commits to the following principles:
- Geographic Focus: Preference for transactions within EU corridors, deemed lower risk due to strong regulatory frameworks. Transactions involving FATF-listed jurisdictions are excluded unless under exceptional circumstances, approved by the MLRO.
- Customer Risk: Priority is given to SMEs operating within clearly defined industries. High-risk sectors (e.g., gambling, cryptocurrency) require enhanced due diligence and explicit MLRO approval.
- Sanctions Compliance: Strict adherence to international sanctions, with no tolerance for transactions involving sanctioned entities, jurisdictions, or individuals.
- Product Risk: While {{firm.name}} offers money remittance services, which are inherently high-risk, the firm effectively manages this risk by implementing a robust control framework.
- Channel Risk: {{firm.name}} acquires its clients through online channels exclusively. To monitor and mitigate channel risk, {{firm.name}} will implement a robust system that includes ID&V (Identity & Verification) and name screening checks.

Alignment with Domestic and International Regulatory Requirements
{{firm.name}} adheres to all applicable laws and regulations, including but not limited to the following:
- UK Regulations: The Money Laundering, Terrorist Financing and Transfer of Funds (Information on the Payer) Regulations 2017, Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (POCA), FCA’s Financial Crime Guide (FCG), and the Senior Managers and Certification Regime (SM&CR).
- International Standards: FATF Recommendations, EU AML Directives, and applicable sanctions laws (e.g., OFAC, UN, EU).
Where conflicts arise between domestic and international regulations, the MLRO escalates the issue to senior management for resolution. Decisions are documented, prioritising the stricter standard unless otherwise justified and approved.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Introduction
body_md: Effective governance and senior management oversight are essential to {{firm.name}}’s ability to meet its financial crime obligations, ensuring compliance with anti-money laundering (AML) and counter-terrorist financing (CTF) regulations. Although {{firm.name}} currently operates as a small-scale organisation with two key individuals, its governance framework is designed to be future-proof, scalable, and adaptable to meet the demands of growth. The senior leadership team, including the Board of Directors, plays a pivotal role in setting the strategic direction for financial crime prevention and embedding a culture of compliance across all operational areas.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Senior Management Accountability
body_md:
At {{firm.name}}, the senior management team is accountable for the effectiveness of the firm’s financial crime controls. The Money Laundering Reporting Officer (MLRO) holds a central position in this structure and has direct and independent access to the Board of Directors to ensure financial crime risks are appropriately identified, managed, and escalated when necessary.
As a small organisation, the MLRO and the second director take on multiple roles to ensure the smooth operation of financial crime controls. However, the governance structure is designed to remain compliant as the organisation scales, ensuring that additional roles and layers of oversight can be added without disruption.
Currently, all issues logged within the financial crime framework are managed through a structured escalation process overseen by the MLRO, who also ensures that issues are documented, tracked, and resolved in a manner that aligns with regulatory requirements.
The table below outlines the roles, responsibilities, and accountability structure within {{firm.name}}'s AML programme. Each role contributes to the implementation, monitoring, and continuous improvement of financial crime controls.

| - Reviews quarterly and annual AML reports |

| - Reviews escalated high-risk cases and approves EDD | - Ensures compliance with FCA Principle 11 |

title: Logging and Resolving Financial Crime Issues
body_md:
When financial crime issues, such as flagged transactions or sanctions breaches, are logged within {{firm.name}}’s framework, the following steps are followed:
- Issue LoggingAll financial crime issues are logged into the firm's transaction monitoring system (TMS) or compliance tracker. Each issue is assigned a unique identifier and categorised based on its severity and nature (e.g., sanctions, suspicious activity, or PEP-related).
- Preliminary AssessmentThe MLRO conducts an initial review to determine the root cause and immediate implications of the issue. This review includes:
- Verifying the transaction details or flagged activity.
- Cross-referencing against sanctions lists and customer due diligence records.
- Reviewing the transaction history and any linked accounts or entities.
- Risk AssessmentThe issue is assessed against the firm’s financial crime risk matrix, considering factors such as the customer’s risk profile, geographic risk, and transaction type. For example:
- High-risk issues are escalated immediately to senior management and, if necessary, reported to external authorities such as the National Crime Agency (NCA).
- Medium-risk issues are subjected to enhanced due diligence, which may involve requesting additional information from the customer or beneficiary.
- Low-risk issues are logged and resolved within the compliance team’s standard processes.
- Decision and EscalationHigh-risk issues that require immediate escalation follow the firm’s escalation process:
- Internal Escalation: The MLRO briefs the Board of Directors within 24 hours, outlining the issue, potential impact, and recommended actions.
- External Reporting: If the issue qualifies as suspicious activity, the MLRO ensures a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) is submitted to the NCA promptly.
- Regulatory Notification: Where applicable, the FCA is notified of significant issues, in line with Principle 11 requirements.
- Resolution and DocumentationOnce a decision is reached, the MLRO oversees the resolution process, which may involve freezing accounts, blocking transactions, or engaging with third-party payment providers. The following steps are taken:
- A clear resolution plan is implemented to mitigate risks and prevent recurrence.
- Detailed records of the issue, investigation, and resolution are maintained for audit and regulatory review.
- Post-Incident ReviewFollowing the resolution of a logged issue, a post-incident review is conducted to identify lessons learned and implement improvements. This includes:
- Evaluating the effectiveness of existing controls in preventing the issue.
- Updating policies, procedures, or thresholds where gaps are identified.
- Providing targeted training to staff to address knowledge gaps or emerging risks.

title: Management Information and Record-Keeping
body_md:
{{firm.name}} employs a robust Management Information (MI) system to track and monitor financial crime issues. Key metrics include:
- Volume and nature of flagged transactions and SARs filed
- Escalation timelines and resolution times for high-risk issues
- Training completion rates and audit findings
MI reports are reviewed monthly by the MLRO and quarterly by the Board. This ensures timely visibility into the effectiveness of financial crime controls.
Records of all logged issues, investigations, and resolutions are maintained for a minimum of five years, in line with regulatory requirements. These records are audited annually to ensure completeness and accuracy.

title: Continuous Improvement and Future-Proofing
body_md:
{{firm.name}}’s governance framework is designed to adapt as the organisation grows. Key measures include:
- Establishing a Compliance Committee to provide additional oversight as the team expands.
- Regularly benchmarking governance practices against FCA guidance and industry best practices.
- Conducting independent reviews of the governance framework to ensure alignment with evolving regulatory expectations.
Embedding Governance in Daily Operations
To ensure governance and oversight are not merely theoretical but embedded in the day-to-day operations of {{firm.name}}, the firm has established detailed operational processes to integrate compliance with financial crime regulations into every customer and transaction touchpoint. This section expands on how {{firm.name}}’s governance framework is implemented in practice, ensuring compliance and effective management of financial crime risks.

title: Decision-Making and Oversight in Practice
body_md:
1. Transaction Monitoring and Decision-Making:Every transaction initiated through {{firm.name}} undergoes a series of automated and manual checks, ensuring that governance principles are applied at the operational level. The MLRO oversees the following steps:
- Automated Screening: Transactions are immediately screened against sanction lists, PEP databases, and financial crime risk thresholds using SmartSearch.
- Risk Scoring: Each transaction is scored based on predefined parameters (e.g., geographic risk, customer profile, and transaction value). Higher-risk transactions are flagged for manual review.
- Manual Review: Flagged transactions are reviewed by the MLRO or second director. Decisions are documented, including any approvals, escalations, or declines.
- Governance Documentation: Each decision is logged in {{firm.name}}’s compliance tracker, providing a clear audit trail. Key details include the reason for the flag, the risk assessment outcome, and the rationale for the final decision.
2. Regular Escalation Protocols:For high-risk issues, the MLRO adheres to structured escalation protocols to ensure timely involvement of senior management and external parties where necessary. Escalation involves:
- A formal review of the flagged issue, including supporting documentation.
- Communication of the findings to the Board, typically within 24 hours for critical risks.
- External notifications, including SAR submissions to the National Crime Agency (NCA), where required.This protocol ensures that governance is actionable and aligned with regulatory expectations, providing confidence that financial crime risks are effectively managed.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Operational Oversight of Policies
body_md:
1. Policy Implementation and Enforcement:The governance structure supports the practical implementation of {{firm.name}}’s key policies, including the AML/CTF, Vulnerable Customers, and Complaints policies. Operationalising these policies involves:
- Training and Awareness: All employees (currently limited to the two directors) undergo onboarding and refresher training covering financial crime risks, governance principles, and specific responsibilities.
- Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): The SOPs for each policy are integrated into daily workflows, ensuring employees understand their roles and actions. For example:
- The Complaints Policy is operationalised through a streamlined process for logging, escalating, and resolving complaints, including those involving joint responsibility.
- The Vulnerable Customers Policy includes specific measures to identify and support vulnerable customers, ensuring compliance with PRIN 6 and the FCA’s FG21/1 guidance.
- Auditing and Monitoring: Policies are reviewed periodically by the MLRO to identify gaps, ensure relevance, and incorporate lessons learned from incidents or regulatory updates.
2. Key Metrics for Policy Effectiveness:{{firm.name}} has established key performance indicators (KPIs) and metrics to evaluate the operational effectiveness of its policies, including:
- The number and resolution times of flagged transactions
- Compliance rates with customer due diligence (CDD) and enhanced due diligence (EDD) processes
- Training completion rates for all employees
- Feedback from post-incident reviews and external audits

title: Transaction Monitoring Framework
body_md: {{firm.name}} operates a comprehensive, multi-layered transaction monitoring framework designed to mitigate risks associated with money laundering, terrorist financing, and other financial crimes. This framework combines advanced technological tools, structured processes, and manual oversight, ensuring adherence to the Money Laundering Regulations 2017 (MLR), FCA’s Financial Crime Guide (FCG), and international best practices.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Objectives of the Framework
body_md:
The transaction monitoring framework serves as a critical component of {{firm.name}}’s broader financial crime compliance strategy. Its objectives include:
- Real-Time Detection and Mitigation: Continuous identification of suspicious activities using a combination of automated tools and manual review processes.
- Alignment with Risk Appetite: Focusing on medium- and low-risk transactions in EU payment corridors while integrating customer-specific and jurisdictional risks.
- Regulatory Adherence: Meeting all domestic and international standards through rigorous processes for monitoring, escalation, and reporting.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Lifecycle of Transaction Monitoring
body_md:
Pre-Execution Screening
Transactions are subject to automated checks before execution to prevent high-risk activities. This process includes:
- Sanctions and PEP Monitoring: Transactions are screened in real time against updated sanctions lists and Politically Exposed Persons (PEPs) databases using SmartSearch.
- Jurisdictional Risk Assessment: Payments involving high-risk or sanctioned jurisdictions are flagged for review. Transactions routed through FATF grey or blacklisted countries are automatically subject to additional scrutiny.
- Threshold Screening: Transactions exceeding pre-defined limits (e.g., £10,000) are flagged for escalation.
- Consistency Checks: The system assesses whether transaction values and routing align with the customer’s historical behaviour.
Pre-execution alerts are categorised based on severity, with immediate escalation for high-risk issues.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Real-Time Monitoring
body_md:
Real-time monitoring systems operate continuously to detect anomalies during transaction processing. Key capabilities include:
- Velocity Monitoring: Identifying structuring through unusually high transaction frequencies.
- Pattern Recognition: Detecting deviations from established customer behaviour, such as sudden changes in transaction size or geography.
- Cumulative Risk Analysis: Aggregating transaction volumes over specified intervals (daily, weekly, monthly) to identify layering or smurfing attempts.
Monitoring tools flag anomalies for compliance review, ensuring potential risks are captured and addressed promptly.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Post-Transaction Analysis
body_md:
All flagged transactions undergo a detailed manual review by the compliance team or the MLRO. This stage incorporates:
- Document Verification: Supporting evidence, such as invoices or contracts, is evaluated for legitimacy.
- Root Cause Assessment: The MLRO analyses the reasons for the flag, such as suspicious jurisdictional patterns or discrepancies in transaction documentation.
- Decision-Making: Transactions are either approved, escalated, or reported to external authorities through a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR).
Post-transaction analysis provides an opportunity to identify systemic risks and refine detection parameters.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Escalation and Reporting
body_md:
When a flagged transaction meets escalation criteria, the following structured workflow is applied:
- Internal Escalation: High-risk transactions are escalated to the MLRO for immediate review.
- SAR Filing: If suspicious activity is confirmed, a SAR is submitted to the National Crime Agency (NCA) within regulatory timeframes.
- Senior Management Reporting: High-risk cases and recurring issues are reported to the Board for strategic input and decision-making.
Escalation protocols are designed to ensure transparency and compliance while mitigating operational risks.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Risk-Based Monitoring
body_md:
The framework operates under a risk-based approach, which ensures resources are focused on higher-risk areas while maintaining oversight of all transactions. Key elements include:
Automated Rules for Risk Detection
- Threshold Alerts: Transactions exceeding £10,000 are flagged for manual review.
- Jurisdictional Risk Flags: Payments to or from FATF grey or blacklisted countries trigger alerts.
- Behavioural Analysis: Sudden changes in customer activity patterns prompt closer scrutiny.
Rules are periodically recalibrated to reflect regulatory changes, emerging typologies, and lessons learned from investigations.
Customer Risk Integration
The transaction monitoring system aligns with {{firm.name}}’s Customer Risk Assessment (CRA) framework, incorporating:
- Country Risk Analysis: High-risk jurisdictions are flagged during the CRA and receive enhanced monitoring.
- Client-Specific Risk: High-risk customers undergo stricter thresholds, more frequent reviews, and tailored monitoring.
- Transaction-Specific Risk: Unusual routing patterns or large-value transactions are prioritised for review.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Alert Handling and Continuous Monitoring
body_md:
Alert Management Workflow
All alerts generated by automated systems follow a structured process to ensure consistency and thorough investigation:
- Triage: Compliance analysts categorise alerts by severity (low, medium, high) and assign priorities.
- Investigation: Alerts are verified against customer profiles and transaction histories.
- Escalation: High-priority alerts are escalated to the MLRO, while low-priority alerts are logged for monitoring.
Continuous Improvement
{{firm.name}} employs a feedback loop to refine monitoring parameters and system thresholds. Real-time updates are implemented based on insights from SARs, regulatory feedback, and thematic reviews.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Technological Integration
body_md:
{{firm.name}} leverages advanced tools to enhance the effectiveness of transaction monitoring:
- SmartSearch: Screens transactions for sanctions, PEPs, and adverse media in real time.
- Onfido: Facilitates robust KYC and KYB processes by verifying customer documentation and identities.
These systems operate in tandem with manual reviews to ensure comprehensive coverage of all risks.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Quality Assurance and Training
body_md:
Quality Assurance Framework
The MLRO oversees regular testing to validate the effectiveness of transaction monitoring controls:
- Scenario-Based Testing: Simulated suspicious activities are used to test detection capabilities.
- Audit Integration: Internal audits evaluate the accuracy and outcomes of flagged transactions.
Staff Training
{{firm.name}} ensures all employees are equipped to manage transaction monitoring effectively through:
- Role-Specific Training: Focused on red flags, escalation protocols, and SAR preparation.
- Annual Refreshers: Updates on regulatory changes and new risk typologies.
- Practical Exercises: Scenario-based drills improve critical decision-making skills.

title: Reporting and Oversight
body_md:
The effectiveness of the transaction monitoring framework is measured and reported to senior management through detailed metrics, including:
- Flagged Transactions: Volume and categorisation by severity.
- SAR Submissions: Number and trends in suspicious activity reports.
- Resolution Times: Average time to investigate and resolve flagged transactions.
Senior management uses these insights to refine policies, allocate resources, and maintain alignment with regulatory expectations.
