title: KYC Process and Requirements
body_md:
{{firm.name}} employs a comprehensive Know Your Customer/ Business (KYC/ KYB) process to ensure compliance with the Money Laundering Regulations 2017 (MLR) and mitigate financial crime risks. This process involves collecting, verifying, and maintaining accurate customer information, which is critical for evaluating customer risk profiles.
- Information Collection:
- Customer Identification:
- Full legal name
- Residential address (recent utility bill or bank statement dated within the last three months)
- Date of birth
- Government-issued identification (passport, national ID card, or driving licence)
- Transaction Details:
- Source of funds
- Purpose of the transaction
- Expected transaction volumes and frequency
- Verification Process:
- {{firm.name}} utilises Onfido for automated ID verification (IDV) to validate the authenticity of documents and biometric matching
- A four-eyes principle is applied to all verifications. Once the IDV process is completed, a compliance officer manually reviews the records to ensure accuracy and completeness
- Sample checks are conducted on 10% of verified IDs monthly as part of the Quality Assurance (QA) framework. This ensures that all records meet regulatory standards and internal compliance expectations
- Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD):
- For high-risk customers, additional documentation is collected, such as:
- Source of wealth
- References from banks or professional institutions
- Detailed transaction histories
- In cases where high-risk customers exhibit irregularities, the MLRO oversees further investigation and escalation, if necessary.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: KYB Process and Requirements
body_md:
The KYB process at {{firm.name}} is equally rigorous, ensuring businesses are adequately vetted and understood before onboarding.
- Information Collection:
- Company Information:
- Full legal name and trading name
- Registration number and country of incorporation
- Registered address
- Ownership and Control:
- Details of directors and senior management
- Identification and verification of Ultimate Beneficial Owners (UBOs) owning 25% or more
- For complex ownership structures, a full corporate chart and explanation of relationships are required
- Business Operations:
- Nature of business and key sectors of operation
- Annual revenue and expected transaction volumes
- Primary customers and suppliers
- Verification Process:
- Documents such as certificates of incorporation, articles of association, and tax filings are reviewed
- Adverse media and sanctions checks are conducted for all key personnel and UBOs using SmartSearch
- For complex structures, independent verification of ownership is conducted to ensure transparency.
- Ongoing Monitoring:
- Regularly scheduled reviews (see periodic review section) assess whether the business continues to meet compliance standards
- A compliance analyst conducts monthly checks on high-risk entities, including refreshed media screenings and transaction evaluations
- Quality Assurance:
- Sample checks are performed quarterly on 10% of KYB files to ensure that verification processes have been correctly followed
- Findings from QA are used to refine onboarding policies and employee training
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Risk Appetite and Alignment with Business-Wide Risk Assessment
body_md: The risk appetite at {{firm.name}} is a living document, reviewed quarterly to ensure alignment with the dynamic risks facing the business. The formal annual review incorporates jurisdictional, product, and transactional risks to maintain alignment with business strategy and regulatory changes.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Current Risk Appetite
body_md:
- {{firm.name}} focuses on transactions within EU corridors, which are deemed lower risk due to robust regulatory frameworks in member states.
- High-risk jurisdictions identified in FATF grey and blacklists are outside the current risk appetite.
- Complex or high-value transactions involving high-risk sectors (e.g., gambling or cryptocurrency) require explicit MLRO approval.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: CRA Integration
body_md:
The CRA framework is directly influenced by the risk appetite:
- Jurisdictional Risk: Geographic risks are flagged in the CRA based on the most recent risk appetite statements.
- Product and Service Risk: Higher-risk products such as cross-border remittances to non-EU countries are flagged for enhanced scrutiny.
- Customer Risk: Customers operating in sectors or regions outside the risk appetite are subject to heightened onboarding and monitoring requirements.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Sanctions Screening and Escalation Procedures
body_md: Sanctions screening is a critical component of {{firm.name}}'s compliance programme, ensuring that transactions, customer relationships, and business partnerships adhere to international sanctions regulations. {{firm.name}} employs a thorough, multi-layered approach to sanctions screening, supported by advanced tools such as SmartSearch, to identify, assess, and address potential risks.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Screening Process
body_md:
{{firm.name}} implements comprehensive sanctions screening measures to prevent violations and ensure compliance:
- Name Screening:
- All customers, associated parties, and business partners are screened against updated sanctions lists, including those maintained by the UN, EU, OFAC, and the UK Office of Financial Sanctions Implementation (OFSI)
- Screening occurs during onboarding, periodic reviews, changes to client details, and before the execution of transactions
- The SmartSearch tool ensures that all global and local sanctions lists are incorporated and updated, enabling real-time identification of potential matches
- Transaction Screening:
- Transactions are screened in real time to detect links to sanctioned entities, jurisdictions, or activities.
- The screening evaluates transaction origins, destinations, routing patterns, and counterparties for potential sanctions risks.
- Data Accuracy and Updates:
- {{firm.name}} ensures that customer and transaction data used in the SmartSearch screening tool is complete and up-to-date.
- Regular updates to the SmartSearch tool ensure that all relevant sanctions lists are included and fully operational.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Handling a Sanctions Hit
body_md:
When a potential sanctions match is identified, a structured escalation process ensures a comprehensive assessment and resolution:
- Initial Review:
- The compliance team gathers detailed information about the flagged customer or transaction, including:
- Customer details and transaction history.
- Relevant supporting documents, such as invoices or contracts.
- External insights, including media reports or notes from sanctions databases.
- The flagged match is cross-checked against sanctions criteria in SmartSearch to confirm its validity.
- Internal Reporting:
- A detailed internal report is prepared, summarising the findings, assessed risk level, and recommended actions.
- The report includes supporting documentation and highlights any significant risks identified during the review.
- Escalation to MLRO:
- The MLRO reviews the internal report and determines appropriate actions, which may include:
- Blocking the transaction.
- Freezing associated accounts.
- Filing a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) with the National Crime Agency (NCA).
- Offboarding the customer in line with established offboarding procedures.
- Senior Management Involvement:
- High-risk or complex cases are escalated to senior management within 24 hours.
- Decisions are logged in the compliance tracker to maintain a comprehensive audit trail.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Ongoing Monitoring and Escalation
body_md:
Sanctions compliance is integrated into {{firm.name}}’s ongoing monitoring processes to ensure continuous oversight:
- Alert Handling and Resolution:
- Alerts generated by SmartSearch are triaged based on severity, with high-priority matches escalated immediately to the MLRO.
- All actions taken, including escalations and resolutions, are documented in the central compliance system for transparency.
- Periodic Review of Customer Status:
- Sanctions screening is repeated during periodic reviews or significant changes in a customer's activity or business relationship.
- Regular monitoring ensures that changes in sanctions lists or customer profiles are promptly addressed.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Control Measures
body_md:
{{firm.name}} employs robust control measures to maintain the integrity and effectiveness of its sanctions screening process:
- System Validation:
- Routine testing of SmartSearch ensures that all mandatory sanctions lists are included and functioning correctly
- Controls are in place to verify that data used for sanctions screening is complete and accurate
- Escalation Protocols:
- Alerts and potential matches are escalated in accordance with clearly defined protocols, ensuring timely resolution
- The MLRO reviews all escalations to confirm appropriate actions have been taken
- Audit and Quality Assurance:
- Regular audits evaluate the effectiveness of sanctions screening controls and identify opportunities for improvement
- Quality assurance reviews ensure consistent application of screening procedures and adherence to escalation protocols
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Feedback Loop and Continuous Improvement
body_md:
{{firm.name}} continuously refines its sanctions screening processes to address emerging risks and ensure compliance:
- Training and Awareness:
- Staff are trained using case studies and examples of sanctions-related incidents to improve their understanding of compliance requirements and escalation procedures
- Role-specific training ensures that relevant personnel are proficient in using SmartSearch and handling flagged transactions
- Threshold Adjustment and Monitoring:
- Lessons learned from previous sanctions hits inform the adjustment of monitoring thresholds and screening parameters in SmartSearch
- Thematic Reviews and Testing:
- Periodic reviews focus on high-risk areas, such as transactions involving sanctioned jurisdictions, to identify patterns and optimise controls
- Testing ensures that the screening tool consistently detects potential sanctions risks across different scenarios
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Governance and Oversight
body_md:
The MLRO and senior management oversee sanctions compliance, with regular reporting ensuring transparency and accountability:
- Monthly reports summarise key metrics, such as the volume of sanctions alerts, escalations, and SAR filings
- Annual audits validate the effectiveness of sanctions screening and provide recommendations for improvement
- A comprehensive sanctions compliance review is conducted periodically to ensure alignment with evolving regulatory requirements and operational needs
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Customer Offboarding
body_md: {{firm.name}} maintains a comprehensive framework for managing customer exits, recognising that effective offboarding represents a critical element of the firm's financial crime control environment. Within the current operational structure, the MLRO holds primary responsibility for all exit decisions, ensuring consistent application of exit criteria whilst maintaining appropriate oversight of the process from initiation through to completion.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Exit Triggers and Assessment
body_md:
Customer exits may be initiated through several defined pathways, each requiring specific assessment and documentation. The MLRO conducts a structured evaluation of potential exits, considering both immediate triggers and broader relationship context to ensure proportionate and justified decisions.
Financial crime concerns constitute primary exit triggers, encompassing significant adverse media discoveries that materially affect the customer's risk profile, particularly where these relate to financial crime or regulatory breaches. The MLRO assesses the credibility and materiality of such information, documenting specific concerns and their impact on the relationship's risk assessment.
Sanctions considerations require immediate action, with the MLRO conducting urgent assessment of any confirmed sanctions matches. This assessment examines both direct matches and connected party relationships, ensuring comprehensive evaluation of potential sanctions exposure.
Persistent non-compliance with information requests presents another key trigger, particularly where this impedes effective due diligence. The MLRO maintains detailed records of information requests, customer responses, and assessment of the impact on {{firm.name}}'s ability to manage financial crime risks effectively.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Exit Implementation Process
body_md:
Upon determining exit necessity, the MLRO initiates a structured implementation process designed to maintain control whilst ensuring fair treatment. This process encompasses several distinct phases, each requiring specific documentation and control measures.
In the initial documentation phase, the MLRO prepares a comprehensive exit memorandum capturing the full rationale for termination. This document synthesises all relevant evidence, including transaction records, correspondence history, and specific control breaches or suspicious behaviour patterns.
Within the current operational context, the exit memorandum serves multiple purposes: it provides necessary audit trail for regulatory oversight, supports defensive SAR filings where required, and establishes precedent for handling similar cases.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Customer Communication Strategy
body_md:
Communication of exit decisions demands careful management to balance regulatory obligations with customer treatment considerations. The MLRO oversees all exit communications, ensuring appropriate handling of potential tipping off concerns whilst maintaining professional standards.
For standard exits not involving active financial crime concerns, {{firm.name}} implements a structured notice period, typically 30 days, providing customers clear guidance on service termination and outstanding transaction management.
Where exits involve financial crime concerns, the MLRO implements enhanced communication protocols. These ensure compliance with tipping off requirements whilst maintaining appropriate records to demonstrate compliance with both financial crime and consumer protection requirements. Communications in such cases undergo additional review to ensure they do not compromise any ongoing investigations or SAR submissions.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Account Closure and Fund Management
body_md:
The account closure phase requires careful management of any remaining funds whilst maintaining transaction monitoring controls. The MLRO oversees the return of customer funds through approved payment methods, ensuring compliance with both financial crime controls and regulatory requirements.
During the closure period, enhanced monitoring remains in place to identify any attempts to initiate unusual transactions or establish new payment patterns. Particular attention focuses on transaction patterns that deviate from established profiles, requiring additional scrutiny before processing. Enhanced scrutiny applies to attempts to initiate payments to new beneficiaries during the notice period, and any indication of structured transactions designed to circumvent monitoring thresholds.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Post-Exit Controls
body_md:
Following relationship termination, {{firm.name}} maintains robust controls to prevent inadvertent re-engagement with exited customers. The technological infrastructure, incorporating SmartSearch and Onfido integrations, provides systematic screening against previously exited customers during any new applications.
The MLRO maintains a secure exit register documenting comprehensive details of all terminated relationships. This register distinguishes between exits driven by financial crime concerns and those stemming from commercial factors, informing future risk assessments and helping identify potential attempts to re-establish relationships through connected structures.
For financial crime-related exits, ongoing screening continues for a minimum of five years post-exit, covering both the exited customer and identified connected parties. This screening duration extends where specific risks or regulatory requirements demand, ensuring {{firm.name}} maintains appropriate oversight of potential future exposure.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Purpose and Scope
body_md: This section outlines {{firm.name}}'s assessment of potential money laundering and terrorist financing risks across its planned operations, in accordance with Regulation 18 of the Money Laundering Regulations 2017 and aligned with the findings of the UK's National Risk Assessment of Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing 2023.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Risk Assessment Methodology
body_md: {{firm.name}} has developed its business-wide risk assessment through careful analysis of the money remittance sector's inherent risks, incorporating guidance from the UK's NRA, FCA publications, and industry best practices. As a pre-launch firm, this assessment focuses on anticipated risks based on our intended business model and the documented experience of the MSB sector.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Customer Risk Factors
body_md:
{{firm.name}} will target small and medium-sized enterprises conducting regular business transactions within EU payment corridors. Based on the NRA's findings and sectoral analysis, we anticipate elevated risks in the following areas:
Corporate customers with complex ownership structures requiring enhanced beneficial ownership verification measures. The NRA specifically highlights the challenges around corporate opacity and the importance of robust beneficial ownership verification in the MSB sector.
Businesses operating in sectors identified as higher risk in the NRA, including:
- Cash-intensive businesses
- Import/export companies with complex supply chains
- Companies with significant cross-border transaction requirements
- Professional service firms handling client money
Our customer acceptance strategy will incorporate specific risk-mitigation measures for these customer types, including enhanced onboarding procedures and transaction monitoring parameters.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Geographic Risk Factors
body_md:
{{firm.name}}'s initial operations will focus on payment corridors between the UK, France, and Germany. The NRA identifies specific risks in cross-border payments, even within apparently lower-risk jurisdictions. Key geographic risk considerations include:
- Regulatory variations between the UK and EU post-Brexit
- Different approaches to beneficial ownership registration across jurisdictions
- Potential exploitation of regulatory arbitrage opportunities
- Risk of payments being ultimately destined for higher-risk jurisdictions outside our intended corridors
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Products and Services Risk Factors
body_md:
Our planned money remittance service inherently carries elevated risks as identified in the NRA. Key vulnerabilities in our proposed service model include:
- Real-time payment processing limiting pre-transaction screening time
- Potential for structured transactions across business accounts
- Challenges in verifying legitimate business purposes for payments
- Risk of our services being used as part of trade-based money laundering schemes
To address these risks, we will implement specific controls including:
- Value thresholds requiring enhanced verification
- Real-time transaction monitoring
- Trade document verification procedures
- Automated pattern detection systems
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Transaction Risk Factors
body_md:
Based on the NRA and sectoral guidance, we anticipate the following key transaction risks:
- Structured transactions designed to avoid thresholds
- Complex payment patterns potentially indicating layering
- Difficulties in establishing normal transaction patterns for new customers
- Challenges in identifying linked transactions across multiple accounts
Our transaction monitoring framework will be calibrated to detect these patterns from launch, with thresholds and parameters based on industry benchmarks and regulatory guidance.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Delivery Channel Risk Factors
body_md:
As a digital-first provider, our delivery channel risks align with specific concerns highlighted in the NRA regarding online financial services:
- Remote customer onboarding and verification challenges
- Digital identity verification risks
- Account access and authentication security
- Cybersecurity threats to payment processing systems
Our planned control framework addresses these through:
- Multi-factor authentication requirements
- Advanced document verification technology
- Biometric identification capabilities
- Regular penetration testing and security assessments
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Control Framework Design
body_md:
Based on this risk assessment, {{firm.name}} has designed a control framework that will incorporate:
Customer Due Diligence:
- Enhanced verification procedures for complex corporate structures
- Real-time screening against sanctions and PEP lists
- Document verification technology for remote onboarding
- Risk-based approach to ongoing monitoring
Transaction Monitoring:
- Real-time screening of all transactions
- Risk-based transaction thresholds
- Pattern detection algorithms
- Automated alert generation
The framework is designed to be scalable as our business grows, with specific focus on:
- Early detection of emerging risks
- Adaptation to new typologies
- Integration of regulatory updates
- Enhancement based on operational experience
This risk assessment will be reviewed prior to launch and updated based on actual operational experience once services commence. Subsequently, it will be reviewed annually or upon significant changes in our business model, external risk environment, or updates to the NRA.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Customer Risk Assessment (CRA)
body_md:
The Customer Risk Assessment (CRA) is central to {{firm.name}}’s Anti-Money Laundering (AML) and Counter-Terrorist Financing (CTF) programme. It provides a structured, risk-based approach to assess potential financial crime risks posed by individual customers. The CRA is designed to ensure compliance with the Money Laundering Regulations 2017 (MLR), Financial Crime Guide (FCG), and FATF recommendations, while also aligning with {{firm.name}}’s current operational focus and future-proofing its risk management capabilities.
At present, {{firm.name}}’s risk appetite is specifically focused on facilitating payments within EU corridors. While the CRA framework is future-proofed to accommodate higher-risk geographies or transaction types, the company’s operational scope and risk exposure are currently limited to EU corridors. This targeted approach ensures heightened risk controls and operational efficiency within the firm’s established parameters.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Country Risk
body_md:
Country risk evaluates jurisdictional factors associated with a customer’s country of incorporation, operations, source of funds, and destination of funds. While the CRA accommodates global jurisdictions, {{firm.name}} currently prioritises EU corridor transactions.
Key Indicators:
- FATF Status: Countries are assessed based on their inclusion on FATF grey or blacklist jurisdictions
- Sanctions Compliance: Jurisdictions subject to UN, EU, or UK sanctions are flagged for enhanced due diligence
- Transparency Indices: Metrics like the Corruption Perception Index (CPI) are factored into risk evaluations
Scoring Example
| Question | Response | Risk Rating | Score |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Country of incorporation | Germany | Low | 1 |
| Country of source of funds | France | Low | 1 |
| Country of destination of funds | Belgium | Low | 1 |
| Presence in FATF grey/blacklist countries | No | - | 0 |

Operational Controls for Country Risk:
- Automated Screening: All jurisdictions are screened against sanctions lists using SmartSearch
- High-Risk Alerts: Transactions involving high-risk countries trigger immediate escalation to the MLRO
- Periodic Reassessments: Country risk profiles are reviewed quarterly to align with FATF updates and geopolitical changes
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Client Risk
body_md:
Client risk evaluates factors tied to the customer’s business model, legal structure, ownership, and operational behaviours. While the CRA is equipped to assess a diverse range of clients, {{firm.name}}’s current client base predominantly includes SMEs operating within the EU.
Key Indicators:
- Business Type: Sectors with higher exposure to financial crime, such as gambling or cryptocurrency, are flagged for additional scrutiny
- Revenue Consistency: Discrepancies between declared revenue and transaction volumes raise concerns
- Ownership Complexity: Structures involving multiple layers or offshore entities are flagged as higher risk
Scoring Example
| Question | Response | Risk Rating | Score |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Industry | Logistics Services | Low | 1 |
| Revenue-to-Transaction Ratio | 51-75% of revenue | High | 3 |
| Ownership Structure | Simple (1-2 layers) | Low | 1 |
| Adverse Media | No | - | 0 |

Operational Controls for Client Risk:
- Enhanced Verification: Onboarding includes detailed reviews of incorporation documents, beneficial ownership, and financial statements.
- Adverse Media Screening: Daily scans ensure that no new risks emerge from client-related media reports.
- Ongoing Profile Monitoring: Client risk is periodically reassessed to reflect operational changes or new compliance risks.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Transaction/Service Risk
body_md:
Transaction/service risk examines patterns, volumes, and payment types to identify irregularities. For EU corridors, this risk remains lower due to robust regulatory oversight, but {{firm.name}} employs comprehensive controls to prevent financial crime.
Key Indicators:
- Transaction Velocity: Unusually high frequency of payments may indicate structuring or layering.
- Payment Types: Single payment types (e.g., bank transfers or card payments) are lower risk than complex combinations.
- Geographic Risk: Routing through high-risk regions is currently outside {{firm.name}}’s operational scope.
Scoring Example
| Question | Response | Risk Rating | Score |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Total transaction volume/month | £100k - £1M | Medium | 3 |
| Average size of individual transactions | £10,000 - £50,000 | Medium | 2 |
| Recipient business nature | Software Services | Low | 1 |

Operational Controls for Transaction/Service Risk:
- Automated Transaction Monitoring: Tools flag anomalies such as frequent high-value transactions or multiple beneficiaries.
- Real-Time Risk Scoring: Transactions are continuously evaluated for potential risks using pre-defined thresholds.
- Alert Escalation: Suspicious transactions are escalated to designated compliance officers for further review.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Risk Scoring and Aggregation
body_md:
CRA Scoring Breakdown for EU Corridor Transactions:
| Risk Domain | Score | Weight | Weighted Score |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Country Risk | 3 | 40% | 1.2 |
| Client Risk | 6 | 30% | 1.8 |
| Transaction/Service Risk | 5 | 30% | 1.5 |

Final Risk Score:
While the CRA framework allows for flexibility to handle more complex or higher-risk scenarios, the current operational focus on EU corridors yields predominantly low-risk profiles.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Operational Workflow for CRA
body_md:
- Risk Assessment During Onboarding:
- Customer provides detailed information on operations, ownership, and transaction patterns
- CRA score is calculated automatically, with high-risk ratings flagged for MLRO review
- Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD):
- Additional documentation (e.g., tax filings, financial audits) is collected for high-risk cases
- EDD may involve in-person or virtual interviews with key stakeholders
- Ongoing Risk Monitoring:
- Dynamic updates to CRA scores based on new information or transaction anomalies
- Alerts triggered by significant changes in risk profiles are immediately reviewed
- Escalation and Reporting:
- High-risk clients or flagged transactions are escalated to the MLRO
- Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) are filed where necessary
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Suspicious Incidents and Suspicious Activity Reporting (SAR) Framework
body_md: {{firm.name}} is dedicated to the prevention of financial crime. The Suspicious Activity Reporting (SAR) framework alerts the National Crime Agency (NCA) and maintains firm awareness of suspicious activity to ensure constant vigilance and compliance. The Suspicious Incident System (SIS) Framework aids in detecting and investigating such activity, ensuring compliance with relevant regulations.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Key Principles
body_md:
- Non-Tipping Off {{firm.name}} strictly adheres to the legal requirement under POCA to avoid "tipping off" customers or third parties about the investigation or submission of a SAR. All communications and actions are conducted discreetly to ensure the confidentiality of the reporting process.
- Comprehensive Data CollectionUpon identifying suspicious activity, {{firm.name}} collects all relevant information to support the investigation and SAR filing, including:
- Customer details: Name, address, date of birth, and any identification documents.
- Transaction details: Amount, date, time, beneficiary details, and payment method.
- Relevant correspondence: Emails, chat logs, and phone records related to the transaction.
- Real-Time EscalationAny suspicious activity detected through automated or manual reviews is immediately escalated to the Money Laundering Reporting Officer (MLRO) for further investigation.
The SIS integrates automation with manual oversight, ensuring that all employees and systems play a role in identifying and addressing financial crime risks.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Identifying Suspicious Incidents
body_md:
Suspicious incidents can be detected through various channels, including automated tools, employee observations, and third-party notifications. The key triggers for identifying suspicious activity include:
| Trigger Source | Examples of Suspicious Indicators |
| --- | --- |
| Automated Alerts | - Unusual transaction patterns flagged by monitoring tools |
| - High-risk jurisdictions or sanctioned entities identified via SmartSearch |
| Employee Observations | - Customer exhibiting unusual behaviour during KYC onboarding |
| - Reluctance to provide documentation or inconsistent information |
| Third-Party Notifications | - Alerts from payment providers or financial institutions regarding flagged accounts |

These triggers are logged in the SIS system to ensure consistent tracking and investigation.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Logging Suspicious Incidents
body_md:
All suspicious incidents must be logged in the SIS immediately upon identification. The following details are recorded:
| Field | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Incident Reference | Unique identifier assigned to each suspicious activity |
| Date and Time | Timestamp when the incident was identified |
| Source of Alert | Origin of the alert (e.g., automated tool, employee observation) |
| Description of Incident | Detailed account of the suspicious activity, including any relevant context |
| Risk Level | Initial risk assessment (e.g., low, medium, high) |

The SIS tracker is integrated with {{firm.name}}’s core compliance systems to ensure that all flagged incidents are escalated for review by the MLRO.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Incident Review Process
body_md:
Each logged incident undergoes a structured review process:
- Initial Assessment
- The MLRO or designated compliance officer reviews the flagged incident within 24 hours.
- Key elements considered include transaction details, customer risk profile, and relevant documentation.
- The risk level is either confirmed or adjusted based on the initial assessment.
- Supporting Evidence Collection
- Additional documentation is requested from the customer if required (e.g., proof of funds, contracts).
- System logs and previous transactions are analysed for supporting context.
- Decision and Action
- Low-Risk Incidents: Logged for monitoring; no further action required.
- Medium-Risk Incidents: Escalated for enhanced due diligence (EDD), which includes further investigation and possible customer engagement.
- High-Risk Incidents: Escalated for senior management review and, where applicable, reporting to the National Crime Agency (NCA) via a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR).
| Stage | Action | Outcome |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Initial Assessment | Review of flagged transaction or behaviour | Risk classification and decision to escalate or log |
| Evidence Collection | Gathering additional data for a comprehensive view | Detailed understanding of the suspicious activity |
| Final Action | Decision to approve, escalate, or report | Final resolution documented and logged in the SIS |
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Escalation and Reporting
body_md:
High-risk incidents that meet the criteria for suspicion of financial crime are escalated as follows:
- Internal Escalation: High-risk incidents are reported to senior management within 48 hours for review and strategic input.
- External Reporting: If the MLRO determines that the incident warrants external reporting, a SAR is submitted to the NCA immediately. The SAR includes:
- Details of the suspicious activity.
- Supporting evidence gathered during the investigation.
- Steps taken by {{firm.name}} to mitigate further risks.
The escalation process ensures compliance with MLR 2017 and minimises risks to the business.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Monitoring and Continuous Improvement
body_md:
The SIS is subject to regular reviews and updates to enhance its effectiveness.
- Incident Analysis: The MLRO conducts quarterly reviews of logged incidents to identify recurring patterns or areas of concern.
- System Calibration: Automated monitoring rules are refined based on the outcomes of past incidents.
- Employee Feedback: Insights from employees who logged incidents are used to improve training and system usability.
- Audit and Governance: Senior management reviews SIS performance metrics, including the volume of logged incidents, escalation rates, and SAR submissions.
| Metric | Purpose |
| --- | --- |
| Incident Volume | Measure the effectiveness of monitoring tools |
| Escalation Rate | Assess the appropriateness of risk classification |
| SAR Submission Rate | Evaluate the robustness of the escalation framework |
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Operational Process for SARs
body_md:
- Flagging Suspicious Activity
- Suspicious activity is detected through:
- Automated transaction monitoring systems
- Manual reviews conducted by compliance analysts
- Customer interactions that raise concerns, such as evasive behaviour or inconsistent explanations
- Initial Investigation
- The MLRO conducts an in-depth analysis of the flagged activity, including:
- Reviewing the customer's risk profile and previous transaction history
- Cross-referencing against internal and external watchlists, including sanctions lists and adverse media checks
- Analysing transaction trends for patterns indicative of money laundering or financial crime
- Enhanced Monitoring
- While under review, the customer's transactions are subject to enhanced monitoring, including:
- Daily review of all subsequent transactions
- Analysis of the customer’s broader transactional behaviour to identify potential trends or repeated suspicious activity
- Increased scrutiny on beneficiaries and counterparties associated with the flagged transactions
- Decision to File a SAR
- If the MLRO determines that the activity meets the threshold for suspicion under POCA, a SAR is prepared for submission to the NCA. This decision considers:
- The level of suspicion and potential criminality involved
- The customer's risk classification and previous activity
- Whether the activity poses an immediate risk to the financial system or requires urgent intervention
- SAR Submission
- {{firm.name}} logs into the NCA’s SAR Online portal to submit the report securely.
- The SAR includes detailed information about:
- The customer and transaction(s) under review
- The grounds for suspicion
- Any supporting documentation or evidence collected during the investigation
- Post-SAR Monitoring
- Following the submission of a SAR, {{firm.name}} continues to monitor the customer's activity for any additional suspicious behaviour
- Repeat incidents or unresolved concerns are escalated to the MLRO for further action, which may include filing additional SARs
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Enhanced Monitoring and Trend Analysis
body_md:
{{firm.name}} leverages its transaction monitoring framework to conduct enhanced monitoring of customers flagged for suspicious activity. Key activities include:
- Pattern Identification: Analysing flagged transactions for recurring behaviours or links to high-risk jurisdictions.
- Geographic Risk Assessment: Evaluating trends in transactions routed through high-risk corridors or involving politically exposed persons (PEPs).
- Customer Behaviour Analysis: Monitoring deviations from established customer profiles, such as unusual transaction frequencies or unexplained changes in business operations.
{{firm.name}} uses the insights gained from enhanced monitoring to:
- Refine transaction monitoring thresholds and rules
- Update risk profiles for customers, beneficiaries, and transaction patterns
- Develop preventative measures to reduce exposure to financial crime risks
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Record-Keeping and Reporting
body_md:
{{firm.name}} ensures all SAR-related records are maintained securely for the minimum required period, as stipulated by regulatory requirements. This includes:
- Copies of submitted SARs and acknowledgements from the NCA
- Documentation of the investigation process, including the rationale for filing the SAR
- Any subsequent actions taken, such as account restrictions or further compliance checks
Regular reporting to senior management provides oversight of SAR trends, including:
- The volume and nature of SARs filed
- Key risk areas identified through SAR analysis
- Effectiveness of monitoring and escalation processes
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Trend Reporting
body_md:
{{firm.name}} uses advanced analytics and data aggregation to identify and understand broader trends in suspicious activity. This approach enables proactive risk management and continuous improvement of monitoring systems.
Key Components of Trend Reporting:
- Transaction Volume and Frequency Analysis
- Regularly analysing transaction data to identify increases in flagged transactions within specific customer segments, industries, or geographies
- Monitoring high-risk corridors and jurisdictions to assess whether risks are increasing or diversifying
- Pattern Detection Across SARs
- Identifying recurring themes or behaviours in SARs submitted, such as:
- Clusters of activity involving related counterparties
- Repeated use of certain transaction types (e.g., splitting transactions to avoid thresholds)
- Jurisdiction-Specific Risks
- Reviewing trends in transaction flows to and from high-risk jurisdictions, including those flagged in the FATF grey or blacklist
- Identifying emerging risks linked to regulatory updates or geopolitical events
- Customer Risk Categorisation
- Segmenting customers by risk levels (e.g., low, medium, high) to track how flagged activity corresponds to risk profiles
- Assessing the effectiveness of risk categorisation criteria based on SAR outcomes
- Reporting to Senior Management
- Compiling quarterly trend reports for senior management and the Board, which include:
- Volume of SARs filed and key triggers
- Emerging risks and recommended mitigations
- Analysis of whether current risk thresholds are appropriate or require adjustment
Example Trend Reporting Metrics:
| Metric | Data Source | Frequency of Review |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Number of SARs submitted | Internal SAR logs | Monthly |
| Commonly flagged transaction types | Transaction monitoring data | Quarterly |
| Emerging jurisdictional risks | FATF updates, SAR analysis | Quarterly |
| Volume of escalated transactions | Escalation logs | Monthly |

These reports ensure senior management has visibility into key risk areas and can take informed decisions on refining compliance processes.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Escalation Procedures
body_md:
{{firm.name}} employs a structured and transparent escalation framework to ensure that all flagged activity receives appropriate attention and timely resolution. These procedures are future-proofed to provide clarity for new team members.
Escalation Framework:
- Initial Flagging
- Transactions are flagged automatically by monitoring systems or manually by staff based on observed anomalies.
- Flags are categorised by risk severity (low, medium, high) to determine the urgency of escalation.
- Preliminary Review
- The MLRO or a designated deputy conducts an initial review of flagged transactions to:
- Confirm whether the activity aligns with known customer behaviour.
- Verify supporting data and contextual information.
- Determine whether immediate action is required.
- Escalation to MLRO
- High-risk or complex cases are escalated directly to the MLRO for further investigation. Escalation triggers include:
- Transactions involving sanctioned jurisdictions or entities.
- Suspicious patterns that may indicate layering or structuring.
- Repeated issues with a specific customer or counterparty.
- Multi-Layered Review Process
- The MLRO conducts a structured analysis, considering:
- Customer risk profile and transaction history.
- Corresponding data from external sources (e.g., adverse media, sanctions lists).
- The MLRO engages with internal subject matter experts, if necessary, to validate findings.
- Decision-Making and SAR Filing
- The MLRO determines whether a SAR should be filed. Criteria include:
- Evidence of money laundering or financial crime.
- The materiality of the transaction.
- Whether the activity aligns with regulatory reporting thresholds.
- If a SAR is warranted, it is submitted via the NCA’s SAR Online portal within prescribed timelines.
- Post-Escalation Actions
- Transactions and accounts flagged during the escalation process are subject to:
- Enhanced monitoring for recurring or evolving risks.
- Temporary holds or restrictions, if necessary, to mitigate immediate risks.
- All decisions and actions are logged to maintain a comprehensive audit trail.
Example Escalation Pathway:
| Escalation Stage | Responsible Party | Key Actions |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Initial Flagging | Compliance Analyst | Review flagged activity, gather data |
| Preliminary Review | MLRO Deputy | Verify context, assess severity |
| High-Risk Escalation | MLRO | Investigate, liaise with stakeholders |
| Decision and Filing | MLRO | Prepare and submit SAR to the NCA |
| Post-Escalation Monitoring | Compliance Team | Implement enhanced oversight |
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Documentation and Future-Proofing
body_md:
- Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs):
- Detailed SOPs ensure all team members, including new starters, can follow clear steps for escalating and handling suspicious activity
- SOPs are reviewed annually and updated to reflect regulatory changes or lessons learned from prior escalations
- Training and Awareness:
- Regular training ensures staff are equipped to identify and escalate suspicious activity effectively
- New starters undergo mandatory onboarding sessions that cover escalation procedures and trend analysis tools
- Audit and Feedback:
- Escalation logs and SAR submissions are reviewed periodically to ensure compliance and identify areas for improvement
- Feedback from audits is incorporated into the escalation framework to maintain alignment with best practices
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Ongoing Monitoring and Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD)
body_md: {{firm.name}} employs a robust framework for ongoing monitoring and Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD) to identify, assess, and mitigate risks associated with financial crime. This process ensures that all transactions and customer relationships are continuously evaluated against regulatory standards and internal risk thresholds.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Enhanced Due Diligence
body_md: Enhanced Due Diligence is applied to higher-risk relationships to ensure {{firm.name}} understands the customer, source of funds, and risk profile in sufficient depth. This includes collecting additional documentation, verifying beneficial ownership, assessing source of wealth and source of funds, and obtaining senior management approval where required. EDD reviews are refreshed more frequently, with documented rationale for risk ratings, any mitigating controls applied, and decisions to onboard or retain the customer.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Ongoing Monitoring Framework
body_md:
Ongoing monitoring is a critical component of {{firm.name}}'s AML programme, designed to provide continuous oversight of transactions and customer activity. By leveraging automated tools and manual reviews, {{firm.name}} ensures that anomalies or deviations from expected behaviour are promptly flagged and investigated.
Key Components of Ongoing Monitoring:
- Automated Monitoring Systems:
- {{firm.name}} employs advanced transaction monitoring systems to screen all transactions in real-time. These systems utilise predefined rules and algorithms to detect suspicious activity, including:
- Transactions exceeding defined thresholds.
- High-frequency or high-value transfers.
- Activity involving high-risk jurisdictions or counterparties.
- Automated alerts are generated for transactions that deviate from expected patterns, triggering further investigation.
- Behavioural Analysis:
- Customer behaviour is continuously assessed against established profiles to identify:
- Significant deviations from typical transaction patterns.
- Changes in transaction volumes or frequencies.
- New or unusual relationships with counterparties.
- Behavioural trends are documented to provide context for future reviews and investigations.
- Periodic Risk Reviews:
- Customer risk ratings are reassessed periodically based on:
- Updated customer information, including changes in ownership or business activity.
- Analysis of transaction history and flagged activities.
- External data sources, such as adverse media or sanctions lists.
- Customers whose risk ratings increase are subject to enhanced scrutiny and monitoring.
- Management Information (MI) Reporting:
- Regular MI reports are produced to provide senior management with insights into:
- Trends in flagged transactions and customer risk ratings.
- Effectiveness of monitoring systems and escalation processes.
- Emerging risks or vulnerabilities in specific corridors or sectors.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: EDD Triggers and Procedures
body_md:
EDD is applied when a customer, transaction, or relationship poses a higher risk of financial crime. This process involves obtaining additional information, conducting deeper investigations, and implementing stricter controls to mitigate risks.
EDD Triggers:
- High-risk jurisdictions identified in FATF grey or blacklists.
- Customers flagged as Politically Exposed Persons (PEPs).
- Unusual transaction patterns, such as structured deposits or frequent cash transactions.
- Adverse media or sanctions-related alerts.
- Discrepancies between declared and observed activities.
EDD Procedures:
- Additional Information Collection:
- {{firm.name}} collects supplementary data to verify the customer's identity, source of funds, and business operations. This includes:
- Detailed ownership structures.
- Contracts or agreements related to the transaction.
- Financial statements and tax records.
- Enhanced Monitoring:
- Transactions involving high-risk customers are subject to more frequent and detailed reviews.
- Real-time monitoring tools are calibrated to apply stricter thresholds and trigger alerts for any deviations.
- Senior Management Approval:
- High-risk transactions or relationships require approval from senior management or the MLRO before processing.
- The rationale for approvals is documented to ensure transparency and accountability.
- Ongoing Review:
- High-risk customers are reviewed at least quarterly to reassess risk levels and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.
- Periodic updates to customer profiles and risk assessments are mandatory.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Operational Aspects of Monitoring and EDD
body_md:
To ensure consistency and clarity, {{firm.name}} has operationalised its monitoring and EDD procedures with clear roles and responsibilities:
| Role | Responsibility |
| --- | --- |
| Compliance Analyst | Conduct initial reviews of flagged transactions and collect additional information |
| MLRO | Oversee all EDD activities, approve high-risk transactions, and file SARs if necessary |
| Senior Management | Provide strategic oversight and approve significant risk decisions |
| Customer Support Team | Liaise with customers to gather required documentation and address queries |

Future-Proofing:
- Detailed Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) ensure new team members can effectively perform monitoring and EDD tasks.
- Regular training sessions are conducted to familiarise staff with system updates, regulatory changes, and emerging risks.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Periodic Risk Reviews
body_md:
{{firm.name}} employs a structured approach to periodic reviews to ensure the ongoing accuracy and relevance of customer risk assessments. These reviews are tailored to the customer’s risk classification and operational profile.
| Risk Level | Review Frequency | Scope of Review |
| --- | --- | --- |
| High Risk | Annual | Full review of the customer profile, including updated documentation, adverse media screening, and review of transaction trends |
| Medium Risk | Every 3 Years | Update KYC documentation, re-assess risk factors, and conduct a detailed analysis of transactional patterns over the review period |
| Low Risk | Every 5 Years | Refresh KYC documentation, verify business activities remain consistent with declared profile, and assess for any emerging risks |

Examples of Key Triggers for Immediate Review
- Change in Ownership: A change in beneficial ownership automatically triggers a re-assessment
- Significant Transaction Deviation: Transactions outside expected patterns result in immediate EDD
- Adverse Media or Sanctions: If the customer or associated entities appear in adverse media or sanctions lists, immediate review and escalation to the MLRO is required
Trend and Behavioural Monitoring
Periodic reviews are complemented by continuous behavioural monitoring to identify emerging risks. {{firm.name}} employs both automated systems and manual analysis to detect and evaluate:
- Changes in transaction patterns: For instance, a low-risk customer initiating high-value transactions over a short period may warrant re-classification
- Shift in geographic corridors: Transactions moving from low-risk EU corridors to higher-risk jurisdictions trigger additional scrutiny
- Customer interaction records: Frequency and tone of customer inquiries, disputes, or operational challenges are assessed for underlying risk signals
Escalation and Documentation
Results from periodic and triggered reviews are meticulously documented. Any findings requiring action are escalated as follows:
- Initial Assessment: The compliance officer reviews flagged findings for accuracy and determines whether escalation is warranted
- Internal Review Meeting: High-risk findings are presented to the MLRO, who determines the next steps, including whether to file a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR)
- MLRO Action: SAR filing with the NCA (if applicable), enhanced monitoring, or customer offboarding
Future-Proofing Measures
{{firm.name}} ensures new team members can seamlessly continue the review processes by implementing:
- Detailed Review Logs: Comprehensive records of each customer’s review history, accessible via the compliance dashboard
- Training Modules: All team members are trained in periodic review requirements, with a focus on identifying trends and behavioural red flags
- Automation Tools: Risk review reminders are integrated into the compliance system, ensuring timely re-assessment of customer profiles
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Training and Competency Framework for AML/CTF Compliance
body_md: ObjectiveTo ensure all staff at {{firm.name}} are equipped with the knowledge and skills to identify, mitigate, and report financial crime risks in line with regulatory requirements and industry standards.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Training Programmes
body_md:
1. Initial Onboarding TrainingEvery new employee undergoes mandatory AML/CTF training within their first week. This training is role-specific and provides:
- An overview of AML/CTF regulations, including the Money Laundering Regulations 2017 (MLRs)
- Company policies and procedures related to financial crime prevention
- Instructions on identifying and escalating suspicious activity
2. Annual Refresher TrainingTo keep employees updated on regulatory changes and evolving financial crime risks, annual refresher courses are required for all staff. These include:
- Updates on relevant regulations (e.g., FATF guidelines, FCA expectations)
- Emerging trends in financial crime, such as typologies of fraud and money laundering
- Company-specific updates to policies, procedures, and risk appetite
3. Role-Specific TrainingSpecialised training programmes tailored to the unique responsibilities of each role:
- Customer-Facing Staff: Identification of red flags during onboarding and transactions, such as unusual documentation or payment patterns.
- Operations Staff: Understanding transaction monitoring processes, using automated tools like SmartSearch, and escalating alerts.
- Management and Compliance: Oversight responsibilities, reviewing flagged transactions, and submission of Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs)
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Competency Assessments
body_md:
To ensure training effectiveness, staff must demonstrate their understanding through:
- Post-Training Assessments: Short quizzes to assess knowledge retention after onboarding and refresher training.
- Periodic Evaluations: Competency tests during annual reviews to identify knowledge gaps or the need for additional training.
- Case Studies and Simulations: Practical exercises where staff respond to real-world scenarios, such as detecting unusual transaction patterns or completing an SAR.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: External Certifications and Professional Development
body_md:
To maintain high standards of expertise, {{firm.name}} encourages key compliance staff to pursue recognised certifications, such as:
- International Compliance Association (ICA) qualifications.
- Association of Certified Anti-Money Laundering Specialists (ACAMS) certifications. {{firm.name}} supports this by offering financial assistance and study leave.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Training Delivery
body_md:
- E-Learning Modules: Interactive online courses for flexible, scalable training delivery.
- In-Person Workshops: Facilitated by the MLRO or external experts for advanced topics or complex scenarios.
- External Training Providers: Leveraging industry specialists for certifications or workshops on advanced AML/CTF topics.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Record-Keeping
body_md:
{{firm.name}} maintains detailed records of all training activities, including:
- Dates of completed training sessions.
- Assessment scores and certifications achieved.
- Renewal dates for refresher training or certifications. These records are reviewed during internal audits to ensure compliance.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Future-Proofing the Training Programme
body_md:
- Regular Updates: Training content is updated annually to incorporate regulatory changes, new threats, and lessons learned from internal reviews.
- Scalable Platform: E-learning modules are designed to accommodate company growth and new hires efficiently.
- Feedback Mechanisms: Anonymous surveys collect employee feedback on training effectiveness, ensuring continuous improvement.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Technology and System Enhancements for AML/CTF Compliance
body_md: ObjectiveTo leverage technology to enhance {{firm.name}}'s ability to detect, monitor, and mitigate financial crime risks while ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Overview of Key Technology Vendors
body_md:
{{firm.name}} relies on several key technology providers as material outsourcers to facilitate its operations. These vendors play critical roles in ensuring seamless service delivery, robust compliance mechanisms, and scalability for future growth.
| Vendor | Function |

| Vercel | Front-end software user interface |
