Additional details about the role and function of each vendor can be found in {{firm.name}}'s comprehensive outsourcing document. To ensure that all technology partnerships remain effective and efficient, {{firm.name}} conducts annual reviews of these contracts. This includes assessing both performance and value for money, with additional checks in place for onboarding new providers, requiring them to undergo stringent outsourcing evaluations.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Key Technology Features and Integration
body_md:
1. Automated Screening and Monitoring (SmartSearch)
- Functionality: SmartSearch conducts real-time screening of customers and transactions against key watchlists (e.g., sanctions, PEPs, and adverse media databases).
- Integration: Connected to {{firm.name}}'s customer onboarding and transaction systems, enabling automated alerts for potential risks.
- Compliance Impact: Minimises manual intervention, reduces false positives, and ensures timely identification of risks.
2. KYC/KYB Verification (Onfido)
- Functionality: Onfido provides identity and business verification services, including document validation and biometric checks.
- Integration: Integrated with the onboarding system to verify customer identities before account activation.
- Compliance Impact: Ensures compliance with regulatory requirements for identity verification while enhancing user experience.
3. Secure Data Management and Scalability (AWS, Supabase)
- Functionality: AWS provides cloud hosting with high availability and security standards. Supabase serves as the back-end database for storing and managing operational and compliance data.
- Integration: Both are integrated with front-end (Vercel) and compliance systems to ensure seamless data flow.
- Compliance Impact: Ensures secure storage and access to sensitive information, adhering to data protection regulations such as GDPR.
4. Cross-Border Payment Processing (Thunes)
- Functionality: Thunes facilitates cross-border payments and ensures compliance with payment corridor regulations.
- Integration: Transactions are routed through Thunes for disbursement to beneficiaries, with built-in compliance checks at the payment processing stage.
- Compliance Impact: Enables adherence to Payment Services Regulations while providing customers with secure, efficient payment solutions.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Operational Oversight and Vendor Management
body_md:
{{firm.name}} ensures robust oversight of its outsourced technology providers by:
- Regular Performance Reviews: Assessing vendor performance against agreed service levels, with a focus on uptime, data accuracy, and compliance effectiveness.
- Audit Rights: Reserving the right to audit key vendors to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements and internal policies.
- Data Flow and Security: Reviewing data flow maps to ensure data is securely transmitted, stored, and processed in line with GDPR and other data protection standards.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Future-Proofing the Technology Framework
body_md:
{{firm.name}} has designed its technology infrastructure to adapt to evolving regulatory and operational needs:
- Scalability: AWS and Supabase provide scalable solutions to accommodate growing transaction volumes and customer data.
- Enhancements: Regular updates to SmartSearch and Onfido systems ensure {{firm.name}} stays aligned with changes in sanctions lists, regulatory requirements, and technological advancements.
- Automation: Expanding automated workflows to reduce manual intervention, improve efficiency, and minimise human error in compliance processes.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Audit and Quality Assurance
body_md:
{{firm.name}} employs a robust Three Lines of Defence model to ensure the effectiveness of its AML/CTF framework and compliance processes. This model is designed to adapt as the firm grows, with plans to incorporate external vendors for additional assurance as operational complexity increases.
- First Line of Defence: Operational teams are responsible for executing day-to-day AML/CTF controls, including onboarding, transaction monitoring, and reporting. They ensure compliance with established policies and procedures.
- Second Line of Defence: The Compliance function oversees the implementation of the AML/CTF framework, conducts regular monitoring, and ensures adherence to regulatory requirements. Monthly reports are presented to the governance committees to maintain transparency and accountability.
- Third Line of Defence: Internal audits provide an independent review of AML/CTF practices. As the firm scales, external vendors will be engaged to enhance assurance activities, offering an objective evaluation of processes and identifying areas for improvement.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Internal Audit Process
body_md:
- Planning and Scope Definition: Each audit begins with a detailed scoping exercise, defining the specific AML/CTF processes to be reviewed (e.g., onboarding, transaction monitoring, suspicious activity reporting). The scope is aligned with identified risk areas and past QA findings.
- Execution: Audits are conducted using a mix of document review, process walkthroughs, and interviews with relevant personnel. This ensures a comprehensive understanding of control implementation.
- Reporting: Findings are categorised by severity (e.g., low, medium, high risk) and include specific recommendations for remediation.
- Action Plan Development: Action plans are developed in consultation with the operational and compliance teams, detailing responsibilities, timelines, and milestones for addressing identified gaps.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Feedback Loop for Audits
body_md:
- Governance Oversight: Audit reports and action plans are submitted to governance committees for approval and monitoring.
- Policy Updates: Findings from audits are used to refine existing policies and procedures, ensuring that they reflect both regulatory expectations and practical improvements.
- Staff Training: Lessons learned from audits feed into training materials, ensuring that staff understand and address identified weaknesses.
As the business grows, {{firm.name}} plans to engage third-party auditors to enhance objectivity and incorporate industry best practices into its AML/CTF framework. These external audits will focus on high-risk areas and provide independent assurance of the firm’s compliance readiness.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Quality Assurance Framework
body_md:
{{firm.name}} has established a Quality Assurance (QA) framework to ensure the ongoing effectiveness of its AML/CTF processes. This framework focuses on evaluating customer onboarding, rejected applications, and ongoing customer relationships to identify gaps and training needs.
Selection Criteria QA reviews are conducted on a representative sample of customers, including:
- Successfully onboarded customers
- Rejected applications
- Active customers undergoing ongoing monitoring
Trend Analysis and Continuous Monitoring The QA process incorporates trend analysis to identify systemic issues or emerging risks:
- Data Aggregation: Transaction patterns, flagged alerts, and rejection reasons are aggregated and analysed.
- Proactive Adjustments: Identified trends inform adjustments to monitoring thresholds, training programs, and resource allocation.
Operational Escalation and Remediation
- Escalation Channels: Issues identified during QA reviews are escalated through a structured process, with timelines for resolution and designated escalation paths (e.g., Compliance team, MLRO, governance committees)
- Remediation Tracking: A centralised system tracks remediation efforts, ensuring accountability and timely resolution of identified gaps
- Feedback into Policies: QA findings are immediately fed back into policy revisions and monitoring criteria to close identified gaps
Monitoring and Reporting
- Monthly Governance Reviews: Governance committees review QA findings and ensure alignment with strategic goals
- Quarterly Updates: Summaries of QA and audit outcomes are shared with senior leadership to maintain focus on high-risk areas
- Annual MLRO Report: Consolidates findings from QA and audit processes, providing a comprehensive view of the firm’s AML/CTF compliance status and improvement efforts
Technology Integration
- Real-Time Dashboards: {{firm.name}} uses real-time dashboards to visualise QA findings and compliance metrics, allowing for immediate action where needed
- Workflow Automation: Automated tools track QA outcomes and link findings to training and policy updates, ensuring a seamless feedback loop
Continuous Improvement The QA framework is designed to foster a culture of continuous improvement. By systematically identifying weaknesses and addressing them through targeted training and process enhancements, {{firm.name}} ensures that its AML/CTF framework remains effective and resilient.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Reporting Governance and Oversight
body_md:
{{firm.name}} maintains a comprehensive framework for meeting its regulatory reporting obligations, recognising the critical importance of timely and accurate submissions in demonstrating effective oversight of financial crime risks. The MLRO serves as the designated point of contact for all regulatory matters, ensuring consistent communication and maintaining clear audit trails of all regulatory interactions.
The reporting framework operates across multiple regulatory touchpoints, encompassing both routine submissions and event-driven notifications. This structured approach ensures {{firm.name}} maintains effective dialogue with supervisory authorities whilst meeting its regulatory obligations through clear communication protocols and robust operational processes.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Suspicious Activity Reporting
body_md:
The submission of Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) forms a cornerstone of {{firm.name}}'s regulatory reporting framework. The MLRO maintains direct oversight of the SAR process, ensuring submissions meet both content requirements and timing obligations whilst maintaining comprehensive supporting evidence.
SAR preparation follows structured methodology ensuring completeness and accuracy:
Initial Assessment:
The MLRO conducts thorough evaluation of suspicious activity, considering:
- Transaction patterns and deviations
- Customer risk profile and history
- Connected party relationships
- Supporting documentation
- Previous SAR submissions
Report Preparation:
SAR content receives particular attention, with the MLRO ensuring comprehensive inclusion of:
- Detailed transaction analysis
- Customer background information
- Connected party details
- Supporting evidence references
- Clear suspicion rationale
The MLRO maintains specific templates ensuring consistent approach to SAR drafting, whilst adapting content to reflect case-specific details. All SARs undergo thorough review before submission through the NCA's SAR Online portal, with specific focus on accuracy and completeness of information.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Annual MLRO Report Structure
body_md:
The Annual MLRO Report provides a comprehensive assessment of {{firm.name}}'s financial crime framework effectiveness. Report preparation follows an established timeline ensuring adequate data collection, analysis and senior management review, commencing three months before year-end.
Structure View
- Executive Summary: effectiveness of framework, resources, systems, risks and strategic recommendations.
- Operational Analysis: SARs, alerts, high-risk transactions, training and staff competency.
- Risk Framework Review: risk assessment, controls, systems, resources and training.
- Statistical Analysis: customer risk, transaction monitoring, SARs, training and quality assurance.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Regulatory Notification Framework
body_md:
{{firm.name}} maintains specific procedures for notifications required under FCA Principle 11, ensuring open and cooperative dialogue with regulators. The MLRO oversees structured assessment of notifiable events, ensuring appropriate escalation and timely communication.
Notification Assessment:
Upon identifying potential notifiable events, the MLRO conducts structured evaluation considering:
- Material control failures
- Significant financial crime incidents
- Compliance breaches
- Operational disruptions
- System failures
The assessment considers multiple factors including:
- Actual and potential impact
- Customer implications
- Control framework effects
- Remediation requirements
- Resource implications
Notification Process:
Where notification is warranted, the MLRO prepares comprehensive submission including:
- Detailed incident description
- Impact assessment
- Immediate mitigating actions
- Remediation planning
- Resource allocation
{{firm.name}} acknowledges its awareness of its reporting obligations, including REP-CRIM.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Communication Protocols and Documentation
body_md:
The MLRO maintains robust protocols for all regulatory communications, ensuring consistency and maintaining clear audit trails. All regulatory interactions follow structured documentation requirements:
Regulatory Communication Logs:
- All regulatory contact details (correspondence, meetings, calls, requests, submissions)
Pre-Submission Review:
- All regulatory submissions are reviewed for accuracy, evidence, and quality, with senior management and legal approval where needed.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Operational Workflow Management
body_md:
The MLRO maintains clear operational workflows for managing regulatory reporting obligations, ensuring consistent processes across all reporting types:
Identification: Monitoring, audits, escalations, alerts, reports
Preparation: Data gathering, analysis, evidence, quality checks, review
Submission: Secure transmission, confirmation, records, tracking, queries
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Quality Assurance Framework
body_md:
Robust quality assurance processes apply to all regulatory submissions ensuring accuracy and completeness. This encompasses structured review and challenge process before any regulatory communication:
Data Quality: Specific validation procedures include source data verification, calculation methodology review, trend analysis, variance investigation, and cross-reference checks.
Review Process: Multiple review layers ensuring accuracy, including initial preparation, technical check, senior management review, final MLRO approval, and post-submission verification.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Continuous Improvement
body_md:
The MLRO maintains systematic approach to framework enhancement:
Feedback Integration: Regular review of regulatory feedback to assess query analysis, submission effectiveness, process improvements, training requirements, and system enhancements.
Trend Analysis: Regular assessment of reporting patterns to evaluate SAR trends and typologies, notification themes, query patterns, system effectiveness, and resource adequacy.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Governance and Oversight
body_md: {{firm.name}} maintains a structured approach to managing changes within its financial crime framework, recognising that effective change management underpins the firm's ability to maintain robust controls whilst adapting to evolving risks and regulatory requirements. The MLRO holds primary responsibility for change management, ensuring appropriate assessment, implementation and monitoring of all material modifications to policies, procedures and controls.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Change Identification and Assessment
body_md:
Changes to the financial crime framework arise through various channels, with the MLRO maintaining oversight of both internal and external drivers. Regulatory developments, including updates to legislation, FCA guidance or industry standards, receive particular attention through systematic monitoring of regulatory communications and industry updates. Internal drivers, such as audit findings, incident reviews or operational feedback, undergo structured assessment to determine necessary framework adjustments.
The MLRO conducts thorough impact analysis for proposed changes, considering implications for existing controls, resource requirements and operational processes. This analysis extends beyond immediate procedural impacts to consider broader effects on risk assessment methodology, monitoring parameters and staff training requirements. Where changes affect technological solutions, the assessment includes detailed review of system modifications and testing requirements.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Implementation Framework
body_md:
Implementation follows structured methodology ensuring controlled deployment of changes. The MLRO prepares detailed implementation plans capturing specific actions, responsibilities and timelines. These plans incorporate necessary updates to documentation, including policies, procedures and workflow guidance, whilst ensuring appropriate version control and audit trail maintenance.
Training requirements receive particular attention, with the MLRO ensuring staff understanding through targeted briefings and competency assessment. Where changes affect operational processes, detailed workflow guidance supports consistent implementation across affected areas. System changes undergo rigorous testing before deployment, with specific focus on maintaining control effectiveness throughout the transition.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Post-Implementation Review
body_md:
Following implementation, the MLRO conducts structured review assessing effectiveness and identifying any necessary refinements. This review considers both technical accuracy and practical operational impact, gathering feedback from affected staff whilst monitoring key performance indicators. Where reviews identify enhancement opportunities, these feed into the change management cycle ensuring continuous framework improvement.
Documentation of changes maintains a clear audit trail from initial identification through to post-implementation review. The MLRO ensures comprehensive record-keeping covering assessment documentation, implementation plans, testing evidence and effectiveness reviews. This documentation supports both internal governance requirements and regulatory oversight, demonstrating robust change management methodology.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Training and Communication
body_md: Change communication follows established protocols ensuring appropriate awareness across affected areas. The MLRO oversees development of training materials and briefing documents, ensuring clear articulation of changes and their practical implications. Where changes affect multiple areas, coordinated communication ensures consistent understanding and implementation.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Quality Assurance
body_md: Quality assurance processes apply throughout the change management cycle, with specific focus on maintaining control effectiveness during transitions. The MLRO oversees testing procedures ensuring changes meet both technical requirements and operational needs. Post-implementation monitoring tracks effectiveness through established metrics, enabling early identification of any required adjustments.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Regulatory Adaptability
body_md: {{firm.name}} maintains a vigilant approach to monitoring regulatory developments to ensure its framework remains aligned with domestic and international requirements. This includes regular horizon scanning of updates from the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), Financial Action Task Force (FATF), and other relevant authorities. These updates are considered across various parts of the AML/CTF framework, particularly in the Customer Risk Assessment (CRA), transaction monitoring protocols, and the Suspicious Activity Reporting (SAR) process. By incorporating these changes promptly and efficiently, {{firm.name}} not only upholds its commitment to compliance but also fosters a proactive risk management culture.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Vendor Oversight and Assurance
body_md: As {{firm.name}} leverages advanced technological tools provided by external vendors, the firm has embedded a robust oversight mechanism to evaluate vendor performance and compliance with contractual obligations. Regular assessments are conducted to ensure that these providers meet operational and regulatory expectations, particularly regarding data security, system integrity, and adherence to AML/CTF requirements. This process is seamlessly integrated into the Vendor Management SOP and supports broader risk management objectives outlined in the governance framework. Future reviews will incorporate lessons learned and evolving industry standards to enhance this critical aspect of the firm’s compliance infrastructure.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Incident Management and Remediation
body_md: The ability to respond to financial crime incidents is a cornerstone of {{firm.name}}’s resilience. The firm has established clear protocols for logging, assessing, and resolving issues related to control failures, operational disruptions, or suspicious activities. These procedures, articulated in the Incident Response SOP, are closely aligned with the escalation pathways and governance processes outlined in the core AML programme. Post-incident reviews play a vital role in driving continuous improvement by identifying root causes, implementing corrective actions, and ensuring that lessons learned are integrated into future controls. This demonstrates the firm’s capacity to manage emerging threats effectively and maintain its commitment to regulatory excellence.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Embedding a Compliance Culture
body_md: {{firm.name}} recognises that an effective AML/CTF programme depends on a culture of compliance embedded across all levels of the organisation. Through ongoing training, transparent communication, and leadership engagement, the firm ensures that financial crime compliance is treated as a shared responsibility. Employees are encouraged to actively identify risks, escalate concerns, and contribute to the firm’s governance objectives. The training programme outlined earlier in this document supports these efforts by equipping employees with the necessary knowledge and tools to uphold the firm’s standards. This culture of vigilance ensures that compliance is not confined to policies but integrated into daily operations.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Future Growth and Scalability
body_md: While {{firm.name}} currently operates with a streamlined structure, its AML/CTF framework is designed to accommodate future growth. The firm’s systems, processes, and governance structures have been developed with scalability in mind, ensuring that additional staff, increased transaction volumes, or new service lines can be seamlessly integrated without compromising compliance standards. This forward-looking approach, referenced throughout the document, ensures that the firm can remain agile and responsive to both business growth and the evolving regulatory landscape. Strategic investments in technology and expertise underscore this commitment to scalability and readiness.
source_template_filename: MFS Financial Crime Policy & Minimum Standards.docx

title: Key Risk Indicators for Proactive Management
body_md: To enhance oversight, {{firm.name}} employs a range of Key Risk Indicators (KRIs) that monitor the effectiveness of its AML controls. Metrics such as the volume and nature of flagged transactions, SAR submission trends, and resolution times for escalated issues are regularly analysed and reported to senior management. These indicators are woven into the firm’s governance processes, providing actionable insights that support data-driven decision-making. By continuously reviewing and updating these KRIs, {{firm.name}} ensures that its risk management remains robust and dynamic, capable of addressing both current and emerging threats.

title: Continuous Benchmarking and Peer Reviews
body_md: In pursuit of operational excellence, {{firm.name}} periodically benchmarks its AML/CTF programme against industry best practices and conducts peer reviews to identify opportunities for improvement. These activities are aligned with the audit and quality assurance frameworks, ensuring that findings are used to refine processes, enhance controls, and improve training outcomes. By comparing its practices with those of leading institutions, {{firm.name}} demonstrates a commitment to maintaining a forward-thinking and adaptable compliance framework. This not only ensures regulatory alignment but also positions the firm as an industry leader in financial crime prevention.
